_header: O God that in time all things did begin
Bibliographic Ghosts: London, British Library Egerton 2642 : this MS contains a prose work on the election, coronation etc. and funerals of emperors, kings, princes etc. No ME verse entered on folio 130.
_description: John Skelton, Poem on Time — nine 8-line stanzas (ababbcbc) and 4 stanzas rhyme royal (stanzas 7, 9, 10-11)

Banna.First Lines:
O god þat in tyme all thingis did begin In tyme thow maid
                    hevin and erd of nocht…
Banna.Last Lines:
…This tyme sall haif ane end that tyme sall nevir faill Bot
                    loss lyfe fra tyme þat tyme cum lifting all away
Banna.Note:
Thirteen 8-line stanzas, ababbcbc, include. refr. ‘Tak tyme quhill
                    tyme is for tyme will away’.
Banna.Facsimiles:
Fox,  Denton,  and  William A. Ringler.  
             The Bannatyne Manuscript: National Library of Scotland Advocates’
                MS. 1.1.6
         London: Scolar Press, in Association with The National Library of
            Scotland, 1980.

                        ed.  
             The Bannatyne Manuscript.
             4 parts in 4 vols. 
             Scottish Text Society
         3rd ser. 5 (1928); n.s. 22 (1928); n.s. 23 (1930); n.s. 26 (1934)
            Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1928-34; ed. by Ritchie et al: 2.208-11.

TCD661.First Lines:
Tyme ys a thyng that no man may Recyste Tyme ys trancitory and
                    Irevocable…
TCD661.Last Lines:
…The calendis of Ianus with his frostes hore That tyme ys when
                    people muste lyve on the store
